newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Belgacom considers large job cuts - paper.
newsitem.headline: Belgacom considers large job cuts - paper.

text.p: Belgian state-controlled telecomunications group Belgacom is considering reducing staffing by some 3,500 to 5,000, Belgian newspaper De Standaard said on Saturday, quoting a Belgacom letter.

It said the letter, drawn up by Belgacom negotiator and head of internal communications Tony Jossa, suggested the phone company would need a staff of only 20,000 to 21,500 by the end of 1998. Belgacom curently employs about 25,100.
The paper said there would be no forced redundancies.
Belgacom said in a reaction that it had sent such a letter to all staff, but that it contained only hypothetical figures based on increased efficiency and improved working methods.
The letter stressed that voluntary redundancy would be the subject of negotiations. The result of the talks, due by the summer, would have to be approved by the government.
Belgacom is 49-percent owned by a consortium of Ameritech, Singapore Telecom, Tele Danmark and three Belgian groups. The remaining 51 percent is owned by the Belgian state.
